Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Illuminating fundamental material properties to enable highly efficient and inexpensive solar cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
The price of electricity generated from solar cells remains too high to be economically competitive with traditional fossil fuel sources in most regions of the US. To effect widespread adoption of sustainable energy technologies, it is imperative that new methods to fabricate inexpensive and high efficiency solar cells be discovered. This project will explore an exciting family of materials known as hybrid organic perovskites (HP), which have shown efficiencies as high as 20% through solution processing. In spite of their superlative performance, much of the fundamental optical and electronic properties of these materials remains unclear, and additional studies are necessary to shed light on avenues for further improvement in efficiency. Optical characterization of these materials will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Yoshihiko Kanemitsu, an expert in ultrafast spectroscopy, at Kyoto University in Kyoto, Japan.

By depositing a layer of the HP on another solar cell material like Silicon or Copper Indium Selenide (CISe), one creates a tandem solar cell that can harness more sunlight and reach even higher efficiencies (>30%). Much of the literature on HP has focused on the lower bandgap (1.6 eV) Methylammonium Lead Iodide composition. However, to maximize the efficiency of a tandem HP-CISe solar cell, the bandgap of the HP must be higher. Previous research has shown that the bandgap may be tuned by replacement of Iodine with Bromine. This research will explore the fundamental optoelectronic properties and carrier dynamics of hybrid perovskites as Bromine composition increases. Specifically, this project will utilize the expertise and equipment of the Kanemitsu lab for femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy (TAS) and photoluminescence lifetime experiments. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the 2015 EAPSI:Japan cohort, I was afforded the opportunity to spend the summer collaborating with Professor Yoshihiko Kanemitsu at Kyoto University, Uji Campus. Our project focused on identification of the key loss mechanisms in solar cell materials through optical characterization of charge carrier dynamics.

Our work this summer concentrated on the earth-abundant, nontoxic, and inexpensive solar cell technology, Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe). This material has been demonstrated to be a promising material that can be easily deposited through solution processing, making it amenable to large-scale manufacturing. In addition, its absorption onset makes it an appealing choice for the bottom cell of a multi-junction cell with the hybrid perovskites. However, the champion devices based off of CZTSSe have only achieved efficiencies of roughly 13%, which lags far behind the dominant technology, crystalline silicon. In order for tandem solar cells based off of CZTSSe to be economically feasible, it is imperative that we better understand the fundamental material properties and improve the optoelectronic quality.

Through the support of Professor Kanemitsu and postdocs in the group, we gained insight into the factors that currently CZTSSe devices. The results from this summer have demonstrated the potential to tune the charge carrier dynamics through both chemical and thermal treatments. Through judicious choice of these treatments, we were able to improve the properties of the material dramatically from the baseline.

This project has established a connection between the University of Washington and Kyoto University that will extend past the brief summer that I was in Japan. There are plans for exchange of samples between the two institutions in order to further evaluate the potential performance of a wide-range of materials systems. It is only through international collaboration (like those seeded by EAPSI) that we will be able to solve the global problems facing society.
